repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - First, Second, and Third Poverty
            Reduction Support Credit/Grant

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First, Second and the
            Third Poverty Reduction Support Credit/Grant (PRSC/G) for
            Rwanda are as follows: overall outcome was satisfactory,
            risk to the development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was rated highly satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: 1) As evidenced by the allocation of expenditures
            under the Government of Rwanda (GoR's) budget over the
            period of the first PRSC/G series, the nominal amount
            allocated to the social sectors and agriculture increased
            due to the overall increase in public expenditure both in
            nominal and real terms, accompanied by an increase in GDP
            over the period. However, the share of the budget allocated
            to these sectors remained steady or decreased slightly (as
            in education). 2) The infrastructure sub sectors of water
            and energy were successfully supported as part of the
            service delivery agenda under the first PRSC/G series.
            Elevating the dialogue on these sub sectors allowed donor
            partners and GoR to address policy issues more efficiently
            and effectively than had been the case exclusively through
            projects. Sector priorities, support for local level private
            operator schemes in water, extra electricity generation
            capacity in energy, that were not being fully addressed
            through projects received support under the PRSC/G series.
            Inclusion in the PRSC/G series also forced these sub sectors
            to examine weaknesses in sector strategies, policy
            frameworks, Medium Term Economic Framework (MTEFs), and
            planning and budgeting, and established a foundation for, or
            accelerated, donor cooperation and the move to sector-wide
            approaches. 3) In large measure, members of the Bank team,
            including the task team leader and sector specialists,
            remained the same over the course of all three PRSC/Gs in
            the series. While this is unfortunately more often an
            exception rather than the rule, continuity in team
            leadership and team members was a contributing factor to the
            success of the program. GoR strongly highlighted the impact
            that team continuity had on the exceptionally robust
            dialogue between GoR and the PRSC/G team. Such continuity
            facilitated the building of strong relationships and trust
            and understanding amongst all parties and allowed for
            consistent follow-through on the agreed reform program. 4)
            While significant progress is evident within sectors, more
            work is needed to strengthen cross-sectoral linkages. The
            health and water sectors have taken steps to coordinate
            their efforts, but much more needs to be done to capture
            synergies between sectors.

5521250.trustfund:
TF021432-UN SPECIAL INITIATIVE FOR AFRICA,TF053317-PHRD-RWANDA: POVERTY REDUCTION

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            and Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper
            (PRSP) provides a comprehensive diagnosis of the causes of
            poverty, and outlines the key objectives and actions
            required for reducing it. The surveys, and the national
            rapid poverty assessments (NPAs) carried out at the
            grassroots level, confirm that living conditions in Rwanda,
            while slowly improving since 1994, continue to be very poor,
            particularly in rural areas. Development partners strongly
            supported Rwanda's PRSP process, and have universally
            commended the Government of Rwanda (GoR) for the
            consultative manner through which it was developed. The PRSP
            was endorsed by the Boards of the Bank and Fund on August
            12, 2002. The strategy was complemented by the development
            of an Medium-Term Expenditure Framework (MTEF). The PRSP
            identifies the private sector as the main engine of growth,
            with the transformation of agriculture and the rural economy
            as the leading source of growth in the near to medium term.
            To deal with the legacies of genocide and structural
            impediments to economic transformation, the PRSP outlines
            five basic building blocks for economic growth and poverty
            reduction-macroeconomic stability, human development, good
            governance, partnership, and the prioritization of public
            actions-and six priority action areas (a) rural development
            and agricultural transformation; (b) human development; (c)
            economic infrastructure; (d) good governance; (e) private
            sector development; and (f) institutional capacity building
            (see Box 2). The PRSP stresses the importance of defining
            sectoral strategies and associated (MTEFs) to guide public
            actions for implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Rwanda - Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            Project : environmental  assessment and social management analysis

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment and social
            management analysis for the Rwanda Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project analyzes the cross-cutting environmental and
            social issues facing Rwanda in each of the four
            PRSC-targeted sectors, i.e., education, health, water, and
            energy, and identifies ways in which the Government can
            enhance its capacity to manage potential environmental and
            social impacts. The report also proposes key measures that
            the Government can take so that sector ministries, local
            governments, and other institutions develop the capacity to
            manage environmental and social issues during the
            preparation and implementation of development programs and
            projects, irrespective of the source of financing.
            Rwanda's key environmental challenges concern soil
            erosion, soil exhaustion, and overgrazing; deforestation;
            impacts from water contamination including health and
            sanitation impacts, and water weed infestation; loss of
            biodiversity and habitats; and wetlands degradation. Adverse
            environmental impacts in the education and health sectors
            will be mitigated through developing an environmental
            education curricula for students and teachers; including
            sewage systems in sanitary facilities and providing water
            from wells or water harvesting; building standpipes in
            canteens and school kitchens; providing energy-saving
            cooking stoves; preparing public health guidelines
            concerning the water and food supply; preparing manuals for
            public health awareness; disposing of medical and human
            waste using locally constructed clay ovens; and training
            public health inspectors and nurses. The Government will
            address environmental impacts such as water
            pollution/contamination by committing to the Water Supply
            and Sanitation Strategy, which aims to provide a
            sustainable, safe water supply and sanitation facilities
            based on management, responsibility, and ownership by users.
            In the Energy Sector, impact mitigation comprise preparing
            environmental guidelines, conducting a Sectoral
            Environmental and Social Assessment for the sector; building
            the capacity of Electrogaz, the national parastatal, for
            environmental management of natural resources; reviewing
            wood fuel policy; launching a public awareness campaign for
            energy efficient use of wood/charcoal awareness; and
            introducing new technologies/design for energy saving
            cooking stoves that use less firewood for more output.
